node.title: Grain growth actions
node.bodyText: I am new to modeling grain growth. I saw that there are two actions available: the GrainGrowthAction and PolycrystalKernalAction. What are they major differences between the two? Also, I have a phase-field model with 5 phases. I want to add polycrystal structure to only one of the phases by Voronoi Tessellation. From what I understand, adding the microstructure only adds more phase parameters and interfacial energy. I know how to generate Voronoi Tessellation in the entire domain, but how to do it in only one phase? Thanks.
@SudiptaBiswas @dschwen

PolycrystalKernalAction only adds the kernels needed for grain growth simulations, whereas GrainGrowthAction also adds the pieces needed to visualize the outputs. For your next question, you might need to modify the initial condition to do what you need. It would depend on how you are initializing different phases. For example, look into the PolycrystalVoronoiVoidIC regarding how to include a void phase.

@SudiptaBiswas Thank you for helping. What outputs can GrainGrowthAction visualize other than bnds? Will GrainGrowthAction completely replace PolycrystalKernalAction?
For the next part, I tried using SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator to get a block of mesh for assigning the grain structure because the phase has a rectangular geometry instead of a void. How is the interfacial width between two domains of mesh handled?

node.title: Asymmetry in shell element model with symmetric loading.
node.bodyText:
I have a 2d shell element based model with full symmetry about the x axis, subject to a uniformly distributed pressure load on one edge, x displacement fixed on the other edge and y displacement fixed at the mid point of the edges. This model is fully symmetrical about the x axis. When run however, the results for stress in the 1(y) direction are asymmetric to a substantial degree (See image of contours). Weirdly however, the y displacements seem to be perfectly symmetrical. When I run a mesh that isn't tapered the y stress vanishes as you'd expect, and the X stress becomes uniform, so it seems that the issue is only arising when the mesh is tapered. I would appreciate any insight/advice that could be given on this as I've somewhat reached the end of my troubleshooting abilities in figuring this one out.
Stress 00 (xx) shows symmetry:

Displacement in x shows symmetry:

Additionally, the displacement in y also seems to show symmetry:

However stress in 01 (xy) and 11 (yy) directions show asymmetry:


The stress values in y are comparable in magnitude to the values in x (160 in yy direction to 1000 in xx) which means this isn't just a numerical error on a value that is vanishingly small.
The input file used:
[Mesh]
  [base]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = ShellTest1.ucd
  []
  [side_sets]
    type = SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator
    input = base
    new_boundary = 'left right'
    normals = '-1 0 0
               1 0 0'
    fixed_normal = true
  []
  [left_side_mid_node]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = side_sets
    new_boundary = left_side_mid
    coord = '0.0 0.0 0.0'
  []
  [right_side_mid_node]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = left_side_mid_node
    new_boundary = right_side_mid
    coord = '4.0 0.0 0.0'
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
  [rot_x]
  []
  [rot_y]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [stress_00]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_11]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_22]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_01]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_10]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_02]
  order = CONSTANT

  []
  [stress_20]

  []

  []
  [stress_21]

  family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [solid_disp_x]
    type = ADStressDivergenceShell
    block = 1
    component = 0
    variable = disp_x
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [solid_disp_y]
    type = ADStressDivergenceShell

    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [solid_disp_z]

    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [solid_rot_x]

    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [solid_rot_y]
    type = ADStressDivergenceShell

    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [stress_00]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_00
    rank_two_tensor = global_stress_t_points_0
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_11]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_11
    rank_two_tensor = global_stress_t_points_0
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_22]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_22

    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_01]
    type = RankTwoAux

    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_10]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_10
    rank_two_tensor = global_stress_t_points_0
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_02]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_02
    rank_two_tensor = global_stress_t_points_0
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 2
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_20]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_20
    rank_two_tensor = global_stress_t_points_0
    index_i = 2
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [stress_12]
    type = RankTwoAux
    variable = stress_12

  []
  [stress_21]
    type = RankTwoAux

  []
[]

[BCs]
  [BC_0]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0.0
    boundary = left
  []
  [BC_1]
    type = ADDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0.0
    boundary = left_side_mid
  []
  [BC_2]
    type = ADPressure
    variable = disp_x

    boundary = right
    use_displaced_mesh = false

[]

[Materials]
  [stress]
    type = ADComputeShellStress
    block = 1
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [elasticity]
    type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorShell
    youngs_modulus = 210000
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 1
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [strain]
    type = ADComputeIncrementalShellStrain
    block = 1
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    rotations = 'rot_x rot_y'
    thickness = 0.1
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = NEWTON
  automatic_scaling = true
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-30
  l_abs_tol = 1e-30
  nl_max_its = 1000
  l_max_its = 1000
[]

[Outputs]
  [outfile]
    type = Exodus
  []
[]

And the mesh file:
25 16 0 0 0

5 1 quad 6 11 12 7 
6 1 quad 7 12 13 8 
7 1 quad 8 13 14 9 
8 1 quad 9 14 15 10 
9 1 quad 11 16 17 12 
10 1 quad 12 17 18 13 
11 1 quad 13 18 19 14 
12 1 quad 14 19 20 15 
13 1 quad 16 21 22 17 
14 1 quad 17 22 23 18 
15 1 quad 18 23 24 19 
16 1 quad 19 24 25 20
I should also mention that mesh refinement doesn't resolve this issue:
Could someone at leas run this in their own moose-app to let me know if the issue is reproducible?
@bwspenc @dschwen @jiangwen84 who works on shell elements?
Anyone had a chance to look at this yet?
@jain651
@hrishiv would you please also look into this? Maybe create a test case along with others (that you are already developing to represent this problem.

@Edward-Eth Thanks for pointing us to a bug in shell element. I was able to replicate it and figure out that the rotation matrix is calculated just once at the start of the simulation and is not stored. Hence, the rotation matrix for the last element was used to transform the stress and strain for all the elements giving incorrect stress and strain distribution. I
was able to get the symmetric stress distribution by storing the rotation matrices. Will open a pull request for this.
Awesome, glad I could be of assistance and thanks for fixing it 👍
Issue resolved pending Pull Request #21385 for the fixed code.

Just wanted to give you heads up with applying the pressure BC to shell element. The pressure is designed to be applied over an area and when you are applying  pressure to the shell edge it uses only two quadrature points. Hence the team decided to generate an error message when pressure is applied to the edge as several MOOSE test cases were failing when a test file with pressure BC was used for shell element. You can use the resultant force to each node/edge instead of the pressure.
How would I set resultant force? Would that be a neumann BC or would it be best to use something like a ConstantRate nodal kernel?

node.title: Adding nodal constraint equation
node.bodyText:
Does MOOSE have a system in place like the linear constraint system in Abaqus  that would allow specific variables at specific nodes sum to zero? Might not necessarily need to be a MOOSE Constraint constraint, but maybe this could be handled with a kernel?
Specifically I'd like to apply this to mesh displacement variables rather than applying typical displacement boundary conditions.

Hello
My guess is no, seems like it would be an object that would contribute to many different variable residuals and it's not commonly done.
But it s totally possible and would not be too too difficult, just need to rewrite the computeJacobian and computeResidual routines.
@lindsayad to make sure
Guillaume
I don't think we currently have an object as generic as you describe, but we definitely have systems that would support it. Either NodalConstraints or NodalKernels should be able to do the job
Thanks. I think I might be able to make it work with NodalKernels. How does the theory for that system compare with regular Kernels, i.e. weak form and Jacobians and such?

NodalKernels were originally created for equations without spatial derivative terms (they could have d/dt terms) but for which the variable was still a spatially varying field. Because there are no spatial derivative terms (at least in the use case the system was originally intended for), there are no weak forms. The equations you are solving for presumably depend on the nonlinear degrees of freedom, so you still have Jacobians

node.title: Use number of nodes in a nodeset in an equation
node.bodyText: Hi, I am attempting to apply an out of plane distributed load to a shell element model. Looking at examples, and with experiments of my own, it seems the ADPressure BC doesn't allow the application of loads in the Z direction on a boundary on a 2D X-Y generated mesh. The example (modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/shell/static/beam_bending_moment_AD.i) shows the use of a ConstantRate nodal kernel to apply an out of plane distributed nodal force, however if you don't know the number of nodes on the boundary while writing the input file, it is impossible to correctly define a distributed load this way. As such I was wondering if it is possible to return the number of nodes in a boundary to a function to calculate a force per node equivalent to a certain desired "total" force (ie pressure x area)

Hello
In a function directly no, but you can use a postprocessor to count the nodes, then use a parsedfunction to use that value in a function.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/NumNodes.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/MooseParsedFunction.html
Guillaume
Is NumNodes able to operate on a subdomain or boundary to return the number of nodes in/on the same? It seems to lack a boundary or block input to allow it to do that?

It cannot. We'd need to add block or boundary restriction.
It's not very hard to do, do you need block or boundary?

If these nodes belong to a sideset, and you know the sideset name/ID, you can get the list of node IDs in that sideset and apply the condition in an Action.
so all you need to do is. make a new action that has a function that sets up the list of node IDs, then take that list and use it as a parameter to set up the BC you're trying to do.
I am not sure which BCs you are trying to use but that much I know.
you can get the boundaryID by name using _mesh->getBoundaryID(name)
and you can use that ID to get the list of nodeIDs _mesh->getNodeList(boundaryID) which returns a std::vector<dof_id_type>
yup from the code-side you can use these routines.

node.title: RandomInterface share the generated random number across different kernels
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am using the RandomInterface to generate a random number inside a kernel. Is there a way to share this exact number for different kernels on the same node?
Thanks in advance,
Khaled

Hello
Looking at the doxygen, I dont think so. Every time the getRandomReal() is called for that node, it gets a new number.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classRandomInterface.html
You could save this real in a material property or an auxvariable if you want to share it across multiple objects on the same elements/qps
Guillaume

Thank you @GiudGiud! I ended up setting up a user object to do just that, it executes in timestep_begin and has a getter function that passes the result without producing new random numbers. I can share the UO for reference here, if it's needed.
But I have another question because the documentation on RandomInterface might be throwing me off a bit. it is saying that

...you don't want to be producing new random numbers with each linear iteration as this can impact the convergence of the solver. You can avoid this problem If you "reset" the random number generators every "linear" iteration...

so that means if I set the setRandomResetFrequency(EXEC_LINEAR) it would keep generating the same number over and over during these linear itterations? what about the next time step? would it generate the same number again? does the seed change after it is being set initially?
The reason I am asking this is because I keep getting the same pattern in my run, I will need to look more into it, but even if I use time(NULL) to provide a unique seed other than the default it seems to be almost identical result.
Thanks again for the reply!
Best,
Khaled

Ah this is a good point. I think it ll indeed reset all the time, between linear iterations.
The random numbers only depend on the location, the seed and the number of numbers previously generated it seems.
I think you should modify the seed of the randomData object at each time step if you want to change the pattern between time steps.
Note that you are getting the same seed between runs on purpose. This really helps debugging to keep the same seed

node.title: Error Compiling and Testing MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hello Everyone,
I am new to the group and to MOOSE. I tried to follow the instructions on the website to install MOOSE for the first time, however, I run into this problem (attached). Any suggestions on how to resolve this issue? Thank you.
Regards,
BI

.

Hello
It looks like it's not finding libmesh. Did you mamba install moose-libmesh ?
Were you following these instructions?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume, thanks for your response. Yes, those are the instructions I followed and everything seemed to be going alright up until when I wanted to compile and test. I actually just redid it to make sure I did not miss any step, and it still gave me the same error message. Thank you

.
this time you forgot to activate the moose environment. You re still in (base)
I did that, same issue. Not really sure what is going on.
what is the output of mamba list ?
This is what I get with that command.

either your mamba is broken and you need to re-instsall it or you did not install the moose dependencies like in the instructions.
Did you run mamba install moose-libmesh ?

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you for your patience. I just don't know what it is, but I removed everything and reinstalled it again but still run into the same errors. And yes, I did mamba install moose-libmesh. Please see attached images. Thank you.

Can you show us the output of cat ~/.condarc
Very likely there is a deprecated channel.

good call. I see idaholab in the list of channels it's pulling from.
Once you have pasted the content of that file, please delete that file then try again. You will need to run:
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
This is it.

node.title: Identification of complex models：the following blocks (ids) do not exist on the mesh
node.bodyText:
My model is more complicated than cylinders, etc. Models can only be imported while being processed. I completed the pre-processing in Trelis, defined blocks, sidesets, and divided grids, but during the execution of moose, the same error the following blocks ( ids) do not exist on the mesh: pla (65535).

But I do have  defined block: pla

My input file should be runnable because I strip out the complex parts of the model and it works.
It is very strange that I sometimes re-process the pre-processing, and it is possible to perform iterative calculations on moose, but after changing the mesh or other operations on this basis, similar problems will occur.
What I want to ask is whether this problem is caused by the loss of mesh file information caused by complex models, and where should I start to solve this problem.

Hello
Which object is returning this error?
How many blocks do you have in the mesh exactly?
Can you share your mesh file? Might be easier to look at it directly.
Guillaume

Solved off-forum (by email).
pla block did not exist after Trelis output the exodus as it was replaced by pla_TETRA and pla_PYRAMID in the exodus file because it contained mixed element

node.title: Debugging Moose in parallel on Mac in VSCode
node.bodyText:
It would be extraordinarily convenient if there was a way to debug moose on multiple cores, within VScode (on macOS).
If anyone has done this, I would appreicate it if you could share what worked for you (your launch.json, other configuration files, etc)

node.title: Thermal Hydraulics Module Exodus File Error
node.bodyText: Hello, I have been trying to access my exodus file output from my most recent input file utilizing the thermal hydraulics module in MOOSE. I have not been able to access the exodus file in either Paraview or Peacock. Every time I go to open the file Paraview or Peacock both crash and I am hit with the error message "paraview quit unexpectedly." I am also getting this error when I try to run the thermal hydraulics module example files. My input file is set up correctly as the I am getting a "solve converged" message in my terminal. Is there any solution where I am able to view my exodus files from the thermal hydraulics module without Paraview crashing on me? Thank you.

Hello
What version of paraview is this?
Guillaume
I am using Paraview 5.10.1

More specifically, the version of paraview I downloaded was:
ParaView-5.10.1-MPI-OSX10.13-Python3.9-x86_64.dmg
I am also using a MacBook Pro. Thanks!

We are currently having issues with this version.
Please install 5.9 or use the legacy exodus reader in 5.10.1
That worked. Thank you for your help!

node.title: Value of field variables along a selected path
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am interested in knowing the value of a field variable (possibly for the nodes or discrete points) along a path i selected in the model. I eventually want to plot the response of this variable along this path. Any suggestions here will be appreciated.
Kind regards,
Arun

Hello
How is this path? Is it a straight line?
If so you may use this vectorpostprocessor:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/LineValueSampler.html
If not straight, you will want to create a new one with your custom path off of the LineValueSampler
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thanks for the reference. It will be a straight path for sure.
This should definitely work.
Kind regards,
Arun
…

 How is this path? Is it a straight line?
